title: Contracts

articles.content: In a free society, men are not forced to deal with one another. They do so only by voluntary agreement and, when a time element is involved, by contract. If a contract is broken by the arbitrary decision of one man, it may cause a disastrous financial injury to the other . . . . This leads to one of the most important and most complex functions of the government: to the function of an arbiter who settles disputes among men according to objective laws.
articles.attribution:
“The Nature of Government,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 110

articles.content:
A unilateral breach of contract involves an indirect use of physical force: it
consists, in essence, of one man receiving the material values, goods or
services of another, then refusing to pay for them and thus keeping them by
force (by mere physical possession), not by right—i.e., keeping them without
the consent of the owner.
articles.attribution:
“The Nature of Government,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 111

articles.content: In a free society, the “rights” of any group are derived from the rights of its members through their voluntary, individual choice and contractual agreement, and are merely the application of these individual rights to a specific undertaking. Every legitimate group undertaking is based on the participants’ right of free association and free trade. (By “legitimate,” I mean: noncriminal and freely formed, that is, a group which no one was forced to join.)

acknowledgement:
“The Nature of Government,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 110
